Package com.rapidminer.belt.buffer

Class Buffers

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.rapidminer.belt.buffer.Buffers
  • public final class Buffers
extends java.lang.Object
    Utility methods for creating mutable temporary buffers. These buffers can then be used to create immutable Columns.
    Author:
    Gisa Meier, Michael Knopf, Kevin Majchrzak

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class Description
      static class  Buffers.InternalBuffers
      Buffer creation methods for internal access.

    • Method Detail

      • realBuffer

        public static NumericBuffer realBuffer​(int length)
        Creates a buffer of the given length to create a Column of type Column.TypeId.REAL. The buffer is initially filled with Double.NaN. If the buffer is completely overwritten anyway realBuffer(int, boolean) can be used with initialize false instead.
        Parameters:
        length - the length of the buffer
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size is negative

      • realBuffer

        public static NumericBuffer realBuffer​(int length,
                                       boolean initialize)
        Creates a buffer of the given length to create a Column of type Column.TypeId.REAL. The buffer is initially filled with Double.NaN if initialize is true.
        Parameters:
        length - the length of the buffer
        initialize - if true the buffer is initially filled with missing values
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size is negative

      • realBuffer

        public static NumericBuffer realBuffer​(Column column)
        Creates a buffer to create a Column of type Column.TypeId.REAL by copying the data from the given column.
        Parameters:
        column - the column to create a copy of
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the given column is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if he given column does not have the capability Column.Capability.NUMERIC_READABLE

      • sparseRealBuffer

        public static RealBufferSparse sparseRealBuffer​(double defaultValue,
                                                int length)
        Creates a sparse buffer of the given length to create a memory efficient sparse Column of type Column.TypeId.REAL. The buffer is initially filled with the given default value.

        Please note that the buffer implementation is thread safe but accessing it from multiple threads will be slow.

        The buffer's efficiency will depend on the data's sparsity. The buffer will usually be memory and time efficient for data with a sparsity of >= 50%.

        The sparse buffer comes with a constant memory overhead so that it is recommended not to use it for very small data (<1024 data points).

        Parameters:
        defaultValue - the data's (usually most common) default value.
        length - the length of the buffer
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size is negative

      • integer53BitBuffer

        Returns:

      • sparseInteger53BitBuffer

        public static Integer53BitBufferSparse sparseInteger53BitBuffer​(double defaultValue,
                                                                int length)
        Creates a memory efficient sparse buffer of the given length to create a sparse Column of type Column.TypeId.INTEGER_53_BIT. The buffer is initially filled with the given default value.

        Please note that the buffer implementation is thread safe but accessing it from multiple threads will be slow.

        The buffer's efficiency will depend on the data's sparsity. The buffer will usually be memory and time efficient for data with a sparsity of >= 50%.

        The sparse buffer comes with a constant memory overhead so that it is recommended not to use it for very small data (<1024 data points).

        Parameters:
        defaultValue - the data's (usually most common) default value.
        length - the length of the buffer
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size is negative

      • dateTimeBuffer

        public static DateTimeBuffer dateTimeBuffer​(int length,
                                            boolean subSecondPrecision)
        Creates a buffer of the given size to create a Column of type id Column.TypeId.DATE_TIME. The buffer is initially filled with missing values. If the buffer is completely overwritten anyway realBuffer(int, boolean) can be used with initialize false instead.
        Parameters:
        length - the length of the buffer
        subSecondPrecision - whether the buffer should have sub-second precision (nanoseconds of the day)
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size is negative

      • dateTimeBuffer

                                            boolean subSecondPrecision,
                                            boolean initialize)
        Creates a buffer of the given size to create a Column of type id Column.TypeId.DATE_TIME. The buffer is initially filled with missing values if initialize is true.
        Parameters:
        length - the length of the buffer
        subSecondPrecision - whether the buffer should have sub-second precision (nanoseconds of the day)
        initialize - if true the buffer is initially filled with missing values
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size is negative

        Throws:

        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the column does not contain date-time data

      • sparseDateTimeBuffer

        public static DateTimeBufferSparse sparseDateTimeBuffer​(long defaultSeconds,
                                                        int length,
                                                        boolean subSecondPrecision)
        Creates a memory efficient sparse buffer of the given size to create a sparse Column of type id Column.TypeId.DATE_TIME. The buffer is initially filled with the default seconds value. Nanoseconds are initialized to zero. Iff subSecondPrecision is false nanosecond inputs will be ignored by the buffer.

        Please note that the buffer implementation is thread safe but accessing it from multiple threads will be slow.

        The buffer's efficiency will depend on the data's sparsity. The buffer will usually be memory and time efficient for data with a sparsity of >= 50%.

        The sparse buffer comes with a constant memory overhead so that it is recommended not to use it for very small data (<1024 data points).

        Parameters:
        defaultSeconds - the (usually most common) default second value in the data.
        length - the length of the buffer
        subSecondPrecision - true when the buffer should have sub-second precision (nanoseconds of the day) and false otherwise.
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size is negative

      • sparseDateTimeBuffer

        public static DateTimeBufferSparse sparseDateTimeBuffer​(java.time.Instant defaultSeconds,
                                                        int length,
                                                        boolean subSecondPrecision)
        Creates a memory efficient sparse buffer of the given size to create a sparse Column of type id Column.TypeId.DATE_TIME. The buffer is initially filled with the default seconds value. Nanoseconds are initialized to zero. Iff subSecondPrecision is false nanosecond inputs will be ignored by the buffer.

        Please note that the buffer implementation is thread safe but accessing it from multiple threads will be slow.

        The buffer's efficiency will depend on the data's sparsity. The buffer will usually be memory and time efficient for data with a sparsity of >= 50%.

        The sparse buffer comes with a constant memory overhead so that it is recommended not to use it for very small data (<1024 data points).

        Parameters:
        defaultSeconds - the (usually most common) default second value in the data represented via an Instant. The nanoseconds will be ignored as they are not stored sparsely.
        length - the length of the buffer
        subSecondPrecision - true when the buffer should have sub-second precision (nanoseconds of the day) and false otherwise.
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size is negative

        Returns:
        the new buffer

      • sparseTimeBuffer

        public static TimeBufferSparse sparseTimeBuffer​(long defaultValue,
                                                int length)
        Creates a memory efficient sparse buffer of the given length to create a sparse Column of type id Column.TypeId.TIME. The buffer is initially filled with the given default value.

        Please note that the buffer implementation is thread safe but accessing it from multiple threads will be slow.

        The buffer's efficiency will depend on the data's sparsity. The buffer will usually be memory and time efficient for data with a sparsity of >= 50%.

        The sparse buffer comes with a constant memory overhead so that it is recommended not to use it for very small data (<1024 data points).

        Parameters:
        defaultValue - the data's (usually most common) default value.
        length - the length of the buffer
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size is negative

        Please note that the buffer implementation is thread safe but accessing it from multiple threads will be slow.

        The buffer's efficiency will depend on the data's sparsity. The buffer will usually be memory and time efficient for data with a sparsity of >= 50%.

        The sparse buffer comes with a constant memory overhead so that it is recommended not to use it for very small data (<1024 data points).

        Returns:
        the new buffer

        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size is negative

      • nominalBuffer

        public static NominalBuffer nominalBuffer​(int length)
        Creates a buffer of the given length to create a Column of type Column.TypeId.NOMINAL. The buffer supports the maximum number of categories supported by Belt (2147483647). The buffer is initially filled with CategoricalReader.MISSING_CATEGORY.

        Please note, that it is recommended to use nominalBuffer(int, int) instead whenever the number of categories is known in advance.

        Parameters:
        length - the length of the buffer
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size is negative

      • sparseNominalBuffer

        public static NominalBufferSparse sparseNominalBuffer​(java.lang.String defaultValue,
                                                      int length)
        Creates a sparse buffer of the given length to create a sparse Column of type Column.TypeId.NOMINAL. The buffer supports the maximum number of categories supported by Belt (2147483647). The buffer is initially filled with the given default value.

        Please note, that it is recommended to use nominalBuffer(int, int) instead whenever the number of categories is known in advance.

        Please note that the buffer implementation is thread safe but accessing it from multiple threads will be slow.

        The buffer's efficiency will depend on the data's sparsity. The buffer will usually be memory and time efficient for a sparsity of >= 50%.

        The sparse buffer comes with a constant memory overhead so that it is recommended not to use it for very small data (<1024 data points).

        Parameters:
        defaultValue - the buffer's (usually most common) default value.
        length - the length of the buffer
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size is negative

      • sparseNominalBuffer

        public static NominalBufferSparse sparseNominalBuffer​(java.lang.String defaultValue,
                                                      int length,
                                                      int categories)
        Creates a sparse buffer of the given length to create a sparse Column of type Column.TypeId.NOMINAL with at most the given number of categories. Trying to use the buffer with more than the specified number of categories will result in an error. The buffer is initially filled with the given default value.

        Please note that the buffer implementation is thread safe but accessing it from multiple threads will be slow.

        The buffer's efficiency will depend on the data's sparsity and number of different categories. The buffer will usually be memory and time efficient for

        • > 65535 categories (32 bit data) and a sparsity of >= 50%.
        • > 255 and <= 65535 categories (16 bit data) and a sparsity of >= 66%.
        • <= 255 categories (8 bit data) and a sparsity of >= 80%.

        The sparse buffer comes with a constant memory overhead so that it is recommended not to use it for very small data (<1024 data points).

        Parameters:
        defaultValue - the buffer's (usually most common) default value.
        length - the size of the buffer
        categories - the number of categories
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size or number of categories is negative

      • nominalBuffer

        public static NominalBuffer nominalBuffer​(int length,
                                          int categories)
        Creates a buffer of the given length to create a Column of type Column.TypeId.NOMINAL with at most the given number of categories. Trying to use the buffer with more than the specified number of categories might result in an error. The buffer is initially filled with CategoricalReader.MISSING_CATEGORY.
        Parameters:
        length - the size of the buffer
        categories - the number of categories
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given size or number of categories is negative

      • nominalBuffer

        public static NominalBuffer nominalBuffer​(Column column)
        Creates a buffer to create a Column of type Column.TypeId.NOMINAL by copying the data from the given column. The buffer supports the maximum number of categories supported by Belt (2147483647). The buffer is initially filled with CategoricalReader.MISSING_CATEGORY.

        Please note, that it is recommended to use nominalBuffer(Column, int) instead whenever the number of categories is known in advance.

        Parameters:
        column - the column to derive the buffer from
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any of the arguments is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the column is not categorical or if the String type is incompatible with the given column

      • nominalBuffer

        public static NominalBuffer nominalBuffer​(Column column,
                                          int categories)
        Creates a buffer to create a Column of type Column.TypeId.NOMINAL with at most the given number of categories by copying the data from the given column. Trying to use the buffer with more than the specified number of categories might result in an error. The buffer is initially filled with CategoricalReader.MISSING_CATEGORY.
        Parameters:
        column - the column to derive the buffer from
        categories - the number of categories
        Returns:
        the new buffer
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any of the arguments is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the column is not categorical, if the specified type is incompatible with the given column, or if the given number of categories is negative
